#Text=Keep a Family Calendar
#Text=Today 's families are busy !
#Text=Keeping everyone 's schedules straight on a family calendar can be a daunting task .

#Text=Even with a plethora of online calendar tools available , many people prefer an old fashioned written calendar , and with a little creativity and preparation , you can turn this pending tsunami into nothing more than a gentle breeze .
#Text=The added bonus is it does n't have to cost an arm and a leg ...
#Text=Steps
#Text=Decide how you want to keep your calendar .
#Text=Some people prefer decorative wall calendars , others prefer desk calendars , yet others prefer white board calendars .
#Text=The important thing is to make sure it has plenty of room to write at least one thing for each person in your family .
#Text=Assign each person in the family a specific " color " .
#Text=All appointments , activities , meetings , etc. for that person will be written in that color .
#Text=Decide how simple or complex you want to make your calendar .
#Text=Some people like to keep it simple , with just times or places .

#Text=Others like to make it more decorative and use stickers or magnets relating to the particular activity ( for example , baseballs for baseball practice or games , musical notes for piano lessons ) .
#Text=Purchase all supplies .
#Text=The supplies needed are listed below under " Things You 'll Need " .
#Text=All of these can be found at most craft stores , " big box " stores ( Target , Walmart ) , office supply stores ( Office Max , Staples ) , or online .
#Text=You can adjust your complexity to fit your budget
#Text=( Obviously , you can skip this step if you already have everything . )
#Text=Fill out your calendar .
#Text=Use one color for each person .
#Text=Fill out as much information as necessary , but try not to get overly detailed .
#Text=The more details you add , the harder it will be to keep the different items straight .
#Text=This is also beneficial if you have multiple activities on one day ...
#Text=if you add too many details , you risk having to " bleed " over into adjoining days .

#Text=Keep the calendar in a place where you will see it every day such as the fridge , the hallway , a shared telecommunications area , etc. If you regularly check your email first thing in the morning , a desk calendar might be the best .
#Text=If you walk into the kitchen initially , a wall calendar would be optimal .
#Text=Tips
#Text=There are pros and cons to each type of calendar .
#Text=What may work for one person may not work for another .
#Text=Do a test run and be prepared to change to a different method if the first does n't seem to be working so well for your family .
#Text=Over-scheduling is a huge issue in families .
#Text=Seeing a calendar with everyone 's schedule will give you a chance to prioritize what really needs doing .
#Text=Before throwing out an old calendar , write down any birthdays or anniversaries in the new one .
#Text=If using a white board calendar , update it at the beginning of the month every month .
#Text=Many people prefer to also keep a small pocket calendar to jot down appointments as they are made or keep a business card holder to collect appointment cards at doctor 's visits .
#Text=When a new appointment is made , update the calendar as soon as possible .
#Text=The longer you wait , the more likely you are to forget to do so .
#Text=Likewise , when a school calendar comes out , write down all days off , early-dismissals , or other important dates right away .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Calendar
#Text=Color markers
#Text=Decorative stickers , magnets , etc.
#Text=Something to attach the calendar to the wall or other suitable surface
